lexUnit.name: stand.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: place in a particular position

sentence.text: They pushed it into the classroom and stood it against a wall .
I closed the lid , snapping the locks , and stood the case against the wall .
We stood people at various locations over the distance to establish a scale reference .
He stood it beneath the skylight just as he heard footsteps pounding up the stairs .
He stood the pencil upright in the centre .
To achieve his dream , he has to stand logic on its head .
Now Proust quite consciously stands this idea on its head , when he writes , and I quote , ` Style is simply the order and movement which grow out of our thought . "
As an additional precaution , you should stand the tray on newspaper .
When I prised her off and tried to stand her on the floor she kept rocking back and sitting on her tail , then falling over sideways and lying there like a stuffed parrot .
Once he took a large bone from the table and stood it on the Queen 's plate .
Stand it on two blocks of wood , fill it with compost , then transfer some of your cuttings to their new home .
She stood a colander under a saucepan and poured sprouts into it .
Stand the tin of syrup in hot water just long enough to make the syrup thin , runny and warm -- not hot .
To be on the safe side why do n't we stand the zinc bath out the rear and let that fill up with rainwater ? "
